@syvineckruyk I don't know if it's the same issue but something similar was happening to me a few months ago -- I took a stab at it in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/569 but it was too slippery to lock down. I think the error message you're seeing is an attempt to alert you that it's happening.

In my case, Celery tasks were failing for non-airflow reasons (out of memory errors due to many simultaneous tasks in a complex subdag). The celery task would therefore be "complete" (as it terminated) but the airflow task would be running and never get updated (since the Celery post-task stuff never runs). It's been a few months since I looked at this but as a starting point, my suggestion is to see if you can diagnose any errors that would be killing the celery workers. I will try to think if there's a way to better self-correct this within Airflow.

Yeah that looks like some external kill -9 where the job could not catch the signal and record the failure.

I'd recommend adding a new `elif` at the pointer bellow, looking for tasks that have failed as far as the scheduler knows, but are still running, and handle the failure. I believe the task instance has a `handle_failure` method that sends email and puts itself in either failed or waiting_for_retry.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L791

The point for removing `requirements.txt` is that not everyone needs every dependencies, depending which operators and hooks you want you should only install the libs you need... maybe people should `pip install airflow[hive]` or whatever sub-package they need when developing. 

We do need to alter the tests to only run the tests that correspond to the libs you have as well...

I think installing `pip install airflow[foo]` does install the core as well which means you need to run `python setup.py develop` after that. Maybe we need to clarify this in the CONTRIBUTING.md
LGTM, @jlowin, as the XCom creator, do you approve?

@jgao54 A common case with XComs is pushing data into the future -- for example, a task creates an XCom when it's run to mark the `last_updated` time, and checks _its own_ XCom the next time it runs. It looks like this PR would break any sort of self-referential XComs. I think that to properly address issue #791, this needs to be an explicit call (or part of `airflow clear`), not something run every time.

This is good functionality but my recommendation is to add this function to `airflow clear`.

Thanks @r39132. There is an open PR regarding the end to end testing, which is the first necessary step in order to reproduce everything described above. 

The PR is here: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/748

It's regularly consuming energy on our side to rebase it and keep it current, so any support and lobbying to get it approved and merged is welcome :)

@jlowin good point, overlooked that use case.  The next question is should  --clear_xcom_data be defaulted to True or False in 'airflow clear'? I think it is more likely to surprise users if XCom data get deleted when all they want to do is clear a TI,  thoughts?

@jgao54 I think this is a great idea and something I think I overlooked originally -- as I think through the implementation, this is the wrinkle:
1. let's say every day a task runs and pushes an XCom
2. now we clear the task for March 19, 2016
3. do we really want to clear every XCom that this task has ever created, or just the ones created by the March 19, 2016 task?

I think when an XCom gets pushed the execution date is part of the metadata. How about when you clear a task, it clears any XComs that it created _which have the same execution date as the cleared task_? Then I would support that being on by default. In the above example, the XCom data pushed on March 19 would disappear but the March 18 data would still be available. What do you think?

Something like this, inside your new function:

``` python
session.query(XCom).filter(
    XCom.dag_id == self.dag_id,
    XCom.task_id == self.task_id,
    # this is the new bit, need to check the correct properties
    XCom.execution_date == self.execution_date
).delete()
```

@jlowin thanks for the feedback! To me your recommendation is intuitive. According to the original issue #791 it may potentially still comes across as ambiguous to end user. But I think for now it's a good fix.

```
  # If the task returns a result, push an XCom containing it
                    if result is not None:
                        self.xcom_push(key=XCOM_RETURN_KEY, value=result)
```

My guess is we should probably add execution_date here as TI's execution_date if we want to use that approach.

Let's keep the extras documented and in sync here:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/docs/installation.rst

@jgao54 the execution date will be automatically inserted (see https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1293). 

Also, after discussion with @r39132, I think my first reaction was too strong. Here's my current thinking:
- DO clear XComs every time a task is run (as in your original PR)
- BUT only clear them for the relevant execution date (using the code I pasted above)

@jgao54 @jlowin Just making my out-of-band comment in-band for posterity : In the issue, the reporter requested that `airflow clear` clear the task instance's xcom. I was concerned about the case where someone uses the UI to clear a task instance, that task instance fails (but might have succeeded earlier), and then a downstream task with `trigger_rule=All done` fires and reads a stale xcom value. Hence, it's best to always clear task_instance side-effects when re-attempted.

@patrickleotardif I was looking for email operator that provided matplotlib or highcharts like charts. If you ever tackle this again, I would be very interested in it!

@jgao54 could you please make one more change -- the use of `main_session=None` is actually outdated. Instead, could you create your function like this:

``` python

@provide_session
def clear_xcom_data(self, session=None):
    """
    Clears all XCom data from the database for the task instance
    """
    session.query(XCom).filter(
        XCom.dag_id == self.dag_id,
        XCom.task_id == self.task_id,
        XCom.execution_date == self.execution_date
    ).delete()
    session.commit()

```

Then you won't need to pass session to `clear_xcom_data()` when you call it, and you won't need to commit after your call either.

I'm going to make my own PR to clean up some of the other leftover uses of `main_session` :)

This has something to do with subdags. When I removed the subdag this issue disappeared. The two dags had different schedule intervals (hourly and daily), which may have had something to do with it.

I'll leave it open for now in case someone else runs into the same problem, but for the time being I got around this by splitting the subdag out into its own dag.

@artwr I'm not opposed to exposing it to the tasks, but you could make the same argument for `pig_properties`. For example, you might want to run different pig operators in different mapreduce queues. If you think there's value in exposing `env` in the `kwargs` to `PigOperator`, we should consider exposing `pig_properties` as well.

Regarding global defaults, we run airflow on a massive hadoop deployment, and changing cluster defaults is not really an option. The folks that maintain pig set default heap space very high (2GB) to account for extreme cases where users would otherwise run out of memory. Our environment is a lot more controlled, and we want to try and optimize memory usage for all `PigCliOperators`, but having a task level value is still probably a good idea.
